political goal: Discredit Ukrainian government
event description:
In April 2020, Facebook uncovered a Russian foreign influence campaign that attempted to drive a wedge between Ukraine and the West through disinformation about the separatist conflict in Eastern Ukraine, the annexation of Crimea, and the ongoing civil war in Syria, NATO, and COVID-19 (Facebook, 2020). 

Shortly after the Russian invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, Facebook uncovered 40 accounts seeking to undermine faith in the Ukrainian government. This network operated across many platforms through fake accounts and websites posing as independent news organizations and ordinary Ukrainian citizens (Gleicher, 2022). The accounts portrayed Ukraine as a ``failed state" and spread misinformation about US, NATO, and EU aid to convince audiences about ``the West betraying Ukraine" (Gleicher, 2022). 

As part of this broader influence effort, the Russian Federal Security Service (FSB) collaborated with Karas Tozak, a Ukrainian politician and local media proprietor. Tozak used his television channels to spread pro-Russian misinformation that disparaged the government of Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelensky in an attempt to undermine public faith in the Ukrainian government (US Dept of Treasury 2022). 

On March 16, 2022, presumed Russian hackers gained access to the Ukraine24 television channel's news ticker to publish fake statements purportedly issued by President Zelensky. The fake statement claimed that he had fled and urged Ukrainians to surrender. Another network circulated a fake video of Zelensky repeating those same claims on Telegram and the Russian social media platform VK (Digital Forensic Research Lab 2022).

political goal: Polarize American politics
event description:
In 2017, a small network of inauthentic social media accounts linked with the Chinese government began posting about U.S. politics in English and Chinese. The accounts posed “as politically engaged users on both sides of the partisan divide” (Nimmo, Eib and Ronzaud, 2020). Researchers identified a group named Trump KAG 2020 that claimed to support U.S. President Donald Trump’s re-election, while a group named Biden Harris 2020 broadly criticized Trump (Gleicher, 2020a). 

In the days leading up to the 2020 U.S. presidential election, the Crime and Security Research Institute identified a network of inauthentic Twitter accounts posting in English and Chinese anti-Trump and anti-Biden content (Crime and Security Research Institute, 2021). A U.S. Intelligence report released in March of 2021 found that China did not attempt to interfere in the 2020 elections (Cohen & Herb, 2021). However, a significant body of evidence documented inauthentic activity linked to the Chinese state.

In 2020, social media accounts also associated with the ’Spamouflage Dragon’ network began posting in English and attacking the administration of President Trump (Nimmo, Fran¸cois, Eib, & Ronzaud, 2020). This network also criticized U.S. foreign and domestic policy, the closure of the Chinese consulate in Houston, Texas, and threats against the video platform TikTok (Nimmo et al., 2019). 

During the 2022 midterm elections, Chinese accounts supported Senators Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz on November 7 and 8, 2021. However, similar accounts discredited the same Senators (Serabian and Kapellmann, 2022).

political goal: Spread COVID-19 disinformation
event description:
From January 2020 to November 2021, a cross-platform network of fake accounts linked with the Chinese influence operation created and hijacked Twitter, Facebook, and YouTube accounts to spread disinformation about the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States (The Virality Project 2022). Many accounts used automated bots that created or amplified content praising the Chinese response to the pandemic, criticized the US response, and attempted to stoke alarm over xenophobic attacks against Chinese Americans (Nimmo et al., 2020). On Facebook and Instagram, other accounts claimed that the US was attempting to pressure the World Health Organization into unjustly blaming China for the pandemic. Employees of state-owned companies such as Sichuan Silence Information Technology Co, Ltd seem to be behind these accounts  (Gleicher et al., 2021).

OneSight Technology Ltd., an internet marketing company with a history of social media amplification work for the Chinese government, was behind many platforms. These accounts used already-trending hashtags to gain visibility and attempted to set their hashtags trending through spam posts and inter-account engagement (Kao and Li 2020).

political goal: Attack the 2022 U.S. midterm elections
event description: Chinese operations discourage Americans from voting in the 2022 U.S. midterm election. The Twitter accounts portrayed Americans who complained about the usefulness of voting. The influence operation framed APT41, a Chinese state-sponsored espionage group, as a U.S. cyber hacker group (Mandiant, 2022). The campaign also tried shifting U.S. policies targeting China (Scott, 2022). Some accounts, for example, discredited the democratic party when politicians from that party claimed they would take the manufacturing out of China (Renouard, 2022).

political goal: Polarize American politics
event description:
Iranian trolls sought to polarize American politics through the creation and distribution of divisive content on topics such as police brutality and race relations. The network employed Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and YouTube (Nimmo and Brookie, 2018; Guynn, 2018b). The account @INeedJusticeNow, for example, which had 61,507 followers and around 13 million video views, focused on issues of police brutality. The account @nornowar, with almost half-million followers and likes, posted a range of content to drive people towards pro-Iranian propaganda designed to look like real news reporting (Q. Wong & Hautala, 2018). Other examples include Michelle Obama holding a sign saying “An Immigrant Took My Job” referring to Slovenia-born First Lady Melania Trump (Guynn, 2018b), while another page created and amplified conspiracy theories related to the 9/11 terrorist attack with a video arguing that 9/11 was an “inside job” executed by the US Government (Bell, 2018). One of the most viewed videos (around 1.5 million views) showed US soldiers laughing at Iraqi children (Nimmo, Brookie, & Karan, 2018a). The accounts aimed to engage followers using comments, memes, and videos, rather than directing other sites. The divisive content suggests that one of the main objectives of these Iranian accounts was to polarize American politics (Nimmo and Brookie, 2018). Another group of 147 Facebook pages and 76 Instagram accounts related to Iranian state media engaged in hacking accounts and spreading malware (Guynn, 2018a).

On March 10, 2020, the National Intelligence Council (NIC) released a declassified report on Foreign Threats to the 2020 US Federal Elections, which stated that Iran launched an influence campaign to sow division between races (National Intelligence Council, 2021). Leading up to the presidential election in 2020, Twitter removed 368 accounts which originated in Iran and sought to interfere in campaigns. Most of the accounts attacked Donald Trump using the hashtag “Resistance,” but a small number of accounts supported Trump’s reelection (Goldstein & Hundley, 2021).

political goal: Discredit Donald Trump in the 2016 and 2020 U.S. presidential elections
event description:
More than 600 accounts and groups were taken down by Facebook in 2018 for “coordinated inauthentic behavior that originated in Iran and targeted people in the US and UK.” In the US, these accounts often posed as left-wing activists, attacking Republican politicians and praising Democratic ones (Nimmo and Brookie, 2018).

By comparison to the Russians, the Iranian hackers were unsophisticated and relatively inept at imitating Americans Sanger (2018). One ad showed a frowning Mr. Trump and declared him “The Worst, Most Hated President in American History,” and another showed two men shaking hands above a conference table and passing money below it and with text: “We call it bribery — they call it lobbying” (examples cited in Sanger, 2018).

On March 10, 2021 the National Intelligence Council (NIC) released a declassified report on Foreign Threats to the 2020 US Federal Elections. The NIC stated that Iran launched an influence campaign against President Trump’s reelection, although the network did not directly promote Trump’s presidential rivals. The campaign also aimed to “undermine public confidence in the electoral process and US institutions” (National Intelligence Council, 2021).

political goal: Discredit Republican Party after 2016 U.S. presidential election
event description:
FireEye, a cyber-security firm, warned Facebook in July 2018 about “Liberty Front Press”, a network of Facebook pages and Instagram accounts with Iranian origins (Intel- ligence, 2018). On August 21 Facebook, drawing on the report, removed 652 users linked to Iranian state media, including accounts, groups and pages. The companies tracked the origin of the accounts using website registration information and IP addresses (Gleicher, 2018c). “Quest 4 Truth”, for example, was linked to Press TV, a news channel affiliated with Iranian media (Gleicher, 2018c; Price, 2018).

Nimmo and Brookie (2018) analyzed the content of the Iranian accounts and found that posts mainly focused on attacking Donald Trump and the Republican Party. They often used distorted images or memes, such as President Trump hugging Kim Jong-un, Supreme Leader of North Korea, with a caption saying “The Nukebook”.

Elements of this FIE were broadly similar to the Russia campaign against Hillary Clin- ton in the 2016 US Presidential Elections Nimmo and Brookie (2018). However, the Iranian network of fake websites and accounts reported by Lim et al. (2019) also aimed at amplifying geopolitical tensions between the United States and countries in the Middle East.

political goal: Promote Iranian foreign policy initiatives in U.S.
event description:
A network thought to be of Iranian origin created social media personas posing as Americans, including journalists and Republican candidates for the U.S. House of Representatives in 2018 (Revelli & Foster, 2019). These accounts posted general pro-Iranian messages, including anti-Saudi, anti-Israeli, and pro-Palestinian themes (Revelli & Foster, 2019). They also posted in opposition to President Trump, and in some later cases posted anti-Iranian messaging, perhaps to build a broader audience or foster polarization. The accounts impersonating American political candidates directly plagiarized tweets and pictures from the real candidates and created original content about the Kavanaugh hear- ings as well as typical pro-Iranian messages (Timberg & Romm, 2019).

In some instances, personas from the network conducted remote interviews with American or UK-based individuals while posing as journalists. Personas in the network published letters in a variety of local and larger newspapers, including the Los Angeles Times and the Seattle times, pretending to be based in the U.S. (Revelli & Foster, 2019).

political goal: Support the Republican party and Donald Trump in 2020 U.S. Presidential Elections
event description:
Seyyed Mohammad Hosein Musa Kazemi and Sajjad Kashian, two indicted Iranian nationals, and other co-conspirators conducted a campaign to influence the US 2020 election to the benefit of then-President Trump (Newman, 2021). They hacked and exploited voting-related websites of a US state and obtained more than 100,000 voters’ information. Posing as members of the Proud Boys group, they sent false information on Democrats exploiting security vulnerabilities of the election apparatus to Republican politicians via Facebook messages and emails. Under the same disguise, they sent intimidating emails to registered Democrats to switch parties and vote for candidate Trump. Finally, they unsuccessfully attempted to hack a US media company with the goal of spreading more election-related false information.

The US Department of Justice determined the efforts to have started in August 2020 and proceeded until November 2020. The two hackers worked as a contractor for Iranian cybersecurity firm Emennet Pasargad–formerly known as Eeleyanet Gostar– which services the Iranian government has used in the past (Department of Justice, 2021).

Note, there is another Influence Effort case involving the US and Iran, in which the latter aimed to attack Donald Trump in the 2016 and 2020 elections, albeit implicating a different set of attacking entities.

political goal: Spread disinformation about the COVID-19 pandemic
event description:
From February to April 2020, a network of fictitious Facebook and Instagram accounts reportedly based in Iran created and amplified a series of cartoons and memes focused on spreading disinformation about the COVID-19 pandemic. The Twitter accounts linked to the International Union of Virtual Media (IUVM), affiliated with the Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corp. IUVM, also ran websites that posed as independent news agencies. The network primarily attempted to use pandemic narratives to disparage the United States, suggesting that COVID was a US bioweapon, that US media reports about COVID were false, and that President Trump was mishandling the pandemic response (The Virality Project 2022).

The network also utilized fake Twitter accounts that vastly amplified Iranian government narratives about the pandemic, including that the US was responsible for its creation (Nimmo et al., 2020). Whereas many accounts were part of other Iranian influence efforts, they pivoted to spreading coronavirus disinformation (Bandeira et al., 2022).

political goal: Discredit Hillary Clinton in the 2016 U.S Presidential election
event description:
Russian tolls targeted the 2016 US presidential election by defaming Hillary Clinton and trying to persuade voters not to choose her. The campaign included three main tactics: stealing information, using bots to amplify stories, and deploying trolls to distort verifiable facts.

First, a team of 14 Russians indicted by a federal grand jury for interfering in the American election, hacked the email accounts of volunteers along with employees of the U.S presidential campaign of Hillary Clinton (the “Clinton Campaign”), including the email account of the Clinton Campaign’s chairman. Mr. Prigozhin and his team, posing as Guccifer 2.0, contacted a US reporter with an offer to provide stolen emails from “Hillary Clinton’s staff.” They then sent the reporter the password to “access a nonpublic, password-protected portion of Dcleaks.com containing emails stolen from Hillary” in March 2016 (Muller 2018).

Second, Mr. Prigozhin also controlled the entity that financed the troll factory, known as the Internet Research Agency (IRA). This company created fictitious social-media personas, spreading falsehoods and promoting messages criticizing Hillary Clinton (Muller 2018). Troll factory tactics included applauding Donald Trump’s candidacy while trying to undermine Hillary Clinton’s (MacFarquhar 2018). Workers for the organization, a number of whom now face US criminal charges, allegedly placed Facebook and Twitter ads carrying fake or harshly critical news about Hillary Clinton. The impact of some of those ads was amplified via automated systems, known as “bots”, whose activity reached millions of Americans (Gordon 2018).

political goal: Attack Democratic party in the 2016 and 2018 U.S. elections
event description:
The Main Intelligence Directorate of the General Staff (GRU) engaged in a concerted long-term effort to damage the political prospects of Democratic Party candidates in two elections cycles. A key method in 2016 was releasing documents stolen through computer intrusions. A group of at least 13 Russians, including businessman and Putin groupie Yevgeny Prigozhin, were indicted for their efforts to hack into the computer networks of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC) and the Democratic Na- tional Committee (DNC). The attackers used the domain actblues.com, which mimicked the domain of a political fundraising platform that included a DCCC donations page, to steal DCCC credentials and modify the DCCC website, redirecting visitors to the actblues.com domain. They stole approximately 2.5 gigabytes of data, including donor records and personal identifying information from more than 2,000 Democratic donors. This information was transferred to registered state lobbyists, as well as senior members of the Trump presidential campaign and online sources of political news (Muller, 2018).

The campaign included fake accounts on social media trying to persuade voters not to choose the Democratic Party. A Russian-created Twitter account, for example, tweeted in February 2018: “The only way the Democrats can win 101 GOP seats is to cheat like they always do with illegals and dead voters.” Another account tweeted instructions for Americans to donate money to defeat Democratic candidates such as Maxine Waters, Elizabeth Warren, and Nancy Pelosi. Russian trolls also defamed Democrats with tweets, using the term “rapefugees”, to associate democratic candidates with cases of sexual assault by migrants (Nimmo, Brookie, & Karan, 2018c).

political goal: ﻿Undermine Barack Obama's image
event description: Russian trolls produced a large volume of tweets defaming President Obama and pushing negative hashtags on Twitter. They also wrote blog posts claiming that “life was good in Russia under Putin and it was bad in the US under Obama” (MacFarquhar, 2018). As in other cases, these trolls were opportunistic and used bots to try to widely spread organic public expressions against Obama.  For example,  these accounts promoted on Twitter and Facebook the case of a fan at a University of Wisconsin football game who came dressed as then President Barack Obama with a noose around his neck (Stein, 2018).

political goal: Discredit American institutions
event description: A coordinated campaign sought to discredit the US Federal Bureau of Investigations (FBI) from 2017 onwards, especially its research on Russian influence operations. This was part of a larger campaign to discredit American institutions (Linvill and Warren, 2018; Nimmo, Brookie, & Karan, 2018a). For example, Russian trolls promoted the effort to force the release of classified documents which allegedly show bias against President Trump at the Justice Department by promoting the hashtag #releasethememo in early- 2018 (e.g. by driving a thousandfold increase in the hashtag’s prominence on January 19, 2018) (RFE, 2018). Trolls linked to the Internet Research Agency (IRA) also specifically targeted African Americans and Mexican Americans in an apparent effort to reduce their respect for government institutions (Howard et al., 2019).

political goal: Support Donald Trump in the 2016 and 2020 U.S Presidential election
event description:
Private firms in Russia, i.e. ‘troll factories’, were paid by the Russian government to spread pro-Trump propaganda on social media (Chen, 2015; Bertrand, 2016). The trolls, for example, used Facebook to organize more than a dozen pro-Trump rallies in Florida during the 2016 election, which were then promoted online by local pro-Trump activists (Poulsen et al., 2017).  A typical post by a Kremlin troll called “Bertha Malone”,  who had at least 400 posts on Facebook, said on this: “if only media had been as bothered by Obama’s ties to the Muslim Brotherhood as they are by Trump’s fake ties to Russia” (Poulsen and Ackerman, 2018). Using data from Facebook, Google, Instagram, Twitter and Youtube between 2015 and 2016, Howard et al. (2019) conclude that the messages created by the IRA were primarily designed to benefit the Republican Party and then- candidate Donald Trump.

Leading up to the 2020 U.S. presidential election, a network of Russian accounts was operated by the Newsroom for American and European Based Citizens (NAEBC), an or- ganization run by people linked to the Russian Internet Research Agency (IRA) (Stubbs, 2020). As in 2016, this campaign promoted Trump’s reelection, targeting far-right users on social media and fake websites (Graphika Team, 2020). This was also the first time that a Russian operation employed the platforms Gab and Parler. According to the U.S. National Intelligence Council, the Russian government and Russian President Putin were responsible for operations aimed at attacking the Biden campaign and supporting Trump (National Intelligence Council, 2021).

political goal: Discredit Conservative critics of Donald Trump after 2016 U.S presidential elections
event description:
Between 2016 and 2018, a number of websites operated with the aim of stealing information from conservative groups critical of then-US President Donald Trump. The targets were former Trump supporters who had subsequently called for more sanctions against Russia. Research by Microsoft pointed out that the websites were created by the group of hackers APT28, which has been publicly linked to a Russian intelligence agency and actively interfered in the 2016 presidential election (Sanger & Frenkel, 2018).

As part of a Russian state-backed campaign, an online article titled “Paul Ryan Opposes Trump’s immigration Cuts, Wants Struggling American Workers to Stay Poor” was manufactured. In it, House Speaker Paul Ryan, a key congressional ally of Trump’s whose 2016-era opposition faded after election day, was to be branded “a complete and absolute nobody incapable of any decisiveness” (Holt, 2017). Another online article, titled “Pro-Amnesty Sen. Marco Rubio:  Trump’s immigration Bill Will not Pass the Senate,” circulated, in which another one-time Trump rival turned supporter, Sen. Marco Rubio of Florida, was supposedly “exposed as a fake conservative who is a traitor to Republican values who in his soul despises the American Constitution and civil liberties” (Holt, 2017).

Yet another online article, titled “McCain says Thinking a Wall Will Stop illegal immi- gration is Crazy,” was posted, targeting the late senator John McCain. The article was intended to brand McCain “as an old geezer” who belongs in a nursing home. McCain’s “pathological hatred” of Trump was a potent area of emphasis, with such “dishonorable scoundrels, such as McCain, immediately aim[ing] to destroy all the conservative voters’ hopes as soon as Trump tries to fulfill his election promises” (Holt, 2017). A similar online article, titled “Dobbs Slams McConnell, Says it is time to Ditch Mitch”, pushed the view that it was time for Senate Republicans leader Mitch McConnell to retire (Holt, 2017).

political goal: Polarize American politics
event description:
Russian trolls and bots promoted discord within the American political landscape over many years. Twitter discovered that nearly 600 Russian-linked troll accounts were promoting conservative, anti-Obama messages from 2014 to 2018 (Weixel, 2018). Russian troll accounts also posted both pro-Affordable Care Act (ACA) and anti-ACA content in 2016. Scholars believe some of that activity was an effort to incite discord between Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders supporters in the 2016 Democratic primary election (Penzenstadler et al., 2018).

Russia-linked accounts also posted about police violence and brutality. Russian bots participated in rhetoric concerning the death of a young black man by police and the Black Lives Matter movement at large (Ackerman, 2018; O’Sullivan et al., 2018). Russian accounts were linked with tweets concerning taking the knee during the National Anthem, immigration (of all varieties), gun control, and the NRA (Beaton & Simon, 2018). Russian addresses were found to be pushing and creating Facebook pages on both sides of the immigration issue. Russian trolls also tried to incite physical protest, by tweeting that people “must take to the streets” if Trump fired Robert Mueller (Hern, 2018; Pen- zenstadler et al., 2018). With regards to gun control, Russian bot accounts tweeted both for and against gun control (Mak, 2018; Frenkel & Wakabayashi, 2018). There is little consistency in ideology across these various efforts, leading many observed to conclude that a key Russian goal was to promote political discord and polarization.

Russian efforts also pushed on environmental issues. For example, Russian trolls exploited the hashtag #NoDAPL and targeted US energy policy from 2015 to 2017 through the use of Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram accounts controlled by the Internet Research Agency (Blacktivist, 2016). An investigation by the Republican majority staff on the House Committee on Science, Space and Technology found more than 9,000 posts produced by 4,334 Russian accounts that dealt with climate and energy issues (Timberg & Romm, 2018). In particular, for more than a week in October 2016, hundreds of accounts tweeted the #NoDAPL hashtag every six hours. #NoDAPL refers to the opposition movement against the Dakota Access Pipeline, which has long been a source of political division in the United States. The #NoDAPL tweets also played up racial and ethnic tensions associated with the pipeline (Hindman & Barash, 2018).

The propaganda included a social media operation run from Ghana which targeted black communities in the US. A deep analysis of the operation’s content concluded that the Ghanian NGO was a front for the Russian IRA (Nimmo, François, Eib, Ronzaud, Smith, et al., 2020).

political goal: Discredit U.S. operations in Syria
event description:
Following the 2011 protests against Syrian President Bashar Assad, Russian operatives enhanced social media efforts promoting “anti-Western, anti-rebel, and pro-Assad narratives” (DiResta & Grossman, 2019). The Russian military intelligence service (GRU) created fake media outlets such as Inside Syria Media Center (ISMC) and associated social media profiles which produced content in English and Arabic. Manufactured journalistic personas published articles across a number of mainstream media websites in the U.S. (St. Clair & Frank, 2018). In 2020, Facebook removed 214 accounts, 35 pages, 18 groups and 34 Instagram accounts associated with this operation (Nimmo, Fran¸cois, Eib, Ronzaud, & Carter, 2020).

After the April 2018 Douma chemical weapons attack in Syria, a Russian-administered social media campaign created accounts claiming to originate in the US (Nassetta and Fecht, 2018). Analysts observed a large increase in the rate of Twitter account creation immediately after the attack, many of which were found to be part of a Russian disinformation campaign against American participation in the Syrian conflict. These accounts used pro-Assad rhetoric and blamed terrorists for attacks on the Syrian people (Nassetta and Fecht, 2018). Russian news agencies such as Sputnik were also found to have reported fake stories about the United States backing Daesh (ISIS) soldiers in Syria in order to fight Assad (Nassetta and Fecht, 2018). These stories were later confirmed to be false by Combined Joint Task Force - Operation Inherent Resolve (Barojan, 2017).

In 2020, Facebook removed an additional network of accounts linked to the Russian GRU, with some content focusing on Syria and the United States (Gleicher, 2020). This campaign rarely focused on domestic U.S. politics, but some assets targeted U.S. involvement in the Middle East. For instance, one Facebook page was called “USA out of Syria” and purported to show a mural of George Floyd in Syria (Nimmo,  Fran¸cois,  Eib,  Ronzaud, & Carter, 2020). At the same time, these accounts praised Syrian President Bashar Al-Assad and Russian involvement in the conflict.

political goal: Support movement for independence in California and Texas
event description: Russian trolls supported the “YesCalifornia” secessionist movement. The group, founded by Luis Marinelli and Marcus Evans, pushed a message of Californian independence. Marinelli previously lived in Russia and opened an ‘embassy’ for his movement there with funding from a Russian NGO (Friedersdorf, 2017). Hours after the 2016 presidential elections, the #calexit movement was mentioned over 100,000 times by Russian bots (Wendling, 2017). Russian bots and trolls also supported the Texas secession movement through the Heart of Texas Facebook page created by the Internet Research Agency (IRA). This page supported the secession of Texas from the US by pushing an event called “Get Ready to Secede” and by using anti-Muslim and anti-Hillary Clinton rhetoric to persuade its audience (Gomez, 2017).

political goal: Support Republican candidate to U.S. senate, Roy Moore
event description: In the 2017 Alabama special election for a US Senate seat,  Kremlin-linked news sites and trolls supported Roy Moore, the Republican candidate accused of sexual misconduct against multiple women (Clifton, 2017). 20,000 to 25,000 tweets were sent out daily using the hashtag #alabamasenaterace from approximately 600 twitter accounts. These accounts were being monitored by the cyber security research project Hamilton 68. It was reported that “Among pro-Moore articles, close to 70% attacked the credibility of the accuser(s), 38% attacked the media, the Washington Post in particular, and one story attacked Lindsey Graham for not defending Moore” (Schafer, 2017). Not all the support that Moore received on the Internet came from Russia. The New York Times reported that a group of “Democratic tech experts” used Russian-style disinformation tactics during Alabama’s 2017 special election in an attempt to splinter support for Moore (Shane & Blinder, 2018). The Washington Post also reported that Facebook suspended accounts used by five people involved in the project (Romm & Timberg, 2018). Although the tactics were similar to those used by Russian trolls, they were not part of this FIE.

political goal: Support Alt-right movements in ﻿ the U.S. 2016 and 2020 presidential election, and 2022 midterms elections
event description:
Russian trolls worked for several years to polarize American politics by pushing complaints by actors on both the political right and the political left on social media. However, these accounts re-tweeted voices from the American "alt-right" significantly more than their left-wing rivals (Nimmo & Karan, 2018). This activity likely had a distinct political goal from the broader polarization effort and is therefore coded as a distinct campaign.

Ahead of the 2020 U.S. presidential election, a Russian campaign again sought to attract far-right American voters. The media organization Newsroom for American and European-Based Citizens (NAEBC), which was run by people associated with the Internet Research Agency, was at the center of this influence effort. The website mainly republished articles from conservative media and created original content favoring white supremacy (Stubbs, 2020). Russian operatives also established profiles on Gab and Parler platforms (Graphika Team, 2020).

In 2022, a network of fake personas spread right-wing political messages about the 2022 elections on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter. Graphika linked the accounts of the Newsroom for American and European-Based Citizens (NAEBC), a fake right-wing news outlet (Graphika Team, 2022).

political goal: Spreading misinformation in the US
event description: According to a report in The New York Times Magazine, Russian trolls from the Internet Research Agency created in 2014 reported about a chemical explosion in the Columbian Chemicals plant in Centerville, Louisiana. “YouTube videos of fake CNN tweets [were] directed at local journalists”, and “text alerts [were] sent to nearby residents”. The source field on Twitter showed that the tweets sent about #ColumbianChemicals were posted using a tool called Mass Post, which is associated with a nonworking page on the domain Add1.ru (Szal, 2015; Chen, 2015). False reports such as a police shooting in Atlanta and an outbreak of Ebola were also spread using these trolls in 2015 (Szal, 2015).

political goal: Discredit Joe Biden in the 2020 U.S Presidential election
event description:
In 2020, the U.S. Office of the Director of National Intelligence stated that Russia was em- ploying a range of measures to target Joe Biden ahead of the presidential election. This effort included pro-Russia Ukrainian officials who propagated false information about corruption and scandals within the Biden campaign (Evanina, William, 2021).  Facebook removed a number of accounts associated with this campaign, linking operators to the Russian Internet Research Agency. This is the first IRA-linked operation in which Facebook accounts were found using AI-generated profile pictures, and the network often promoted a fake news outlet called peacedata.net which posted in English and Arabic (Nimmo, Francois, Eib and Ronzaud, 2020). In addition to attracting a left-wing audience and criticizing the Biden campaign, the network posted about race protests, accusations of U.S. war crimes, and corruption. Attacks on liberal candidates and policies are consistent with the IRA’s activities in 2016 which targeted then-candidate Hillary Clinton (Nimmo, Francois, Eib and Ronzaud, 2020). Related accounts were removed from Twitter and LinkedIn, attempting to build personas which appeared authentic (Allyn, 2020).

Russian military hackers associated with the group known as Fancy Bear or APT28 also targeted Ukrainian gas company Burisma where Joe Biden’s son, Hunter Biden, served on the board (Greenberg, 2020). According to The New York Times, the attack seemed aimed at producing “embarassing material on the Bidens,” similar to emails obtained by Russian hackers from the Hillary Clinton campaign in 2016 (Perlroth & Rosenberg, 2020).

An additional component of undermining the Democratic presidential candidacy was supporting the campaign of Senator Bernie Sanders (Harris et al., 2020). Sanders received a disproportionate amount of positive coverage on Russian news agencies RT and Sputnik as well as inauthentic social media accounts on Facebook and Instagram (Mak, 2020).

political goal: Spread disinformation about the COVID-19 pandemic
event description:
From November 2020 and June 2021, Russian-linked actors spread disinformation about the coronavirus in the United States (The Virality Project 2022). 

The operation linked to the Internet Research Agency (IRA) uses memes to create and amplify anti-vaccine conspiracy theories through a network of fake accounts on Gab, Parler, Facebook, Instagram, and the far-right forum "Patriots.Win" (Graphika 2021).

Another operation from Fazze, a marketing firm suspected of pro-regime ties to the Russian government, criticized the Biden administration's response to COVID-19 and suggested that Biden benefited from the Trump administration's vaccine efforts (The Virality Project 2022).

political goal: Attack Hillary Clinton in the 2016 U.S Presidential election
event description: The campaign to target then-candidate Hillary Clinton involved substantial activity from contractors funded by an unknown country. Veles, a small town in Macedonia,  hosted at least 100 websites creating fake stories against Hillary Clinton (Subramanian, 2017). For example, a story titled “Hillary Clinton In 2013: I Would Like To See People Like Donald Trump Run For Office; They’re Honest And Can’t Be Bought.” was written by ConservativeState.com. The post received 480,000 shares, reactions, and comments on Facebook. This number of shares is high relative to some New York Time’s posts about the US presidential elections, which receive around 175,000 shares in the same social network (Silverman & Lawrence, 2016). There is some evidence suggesting that one group of the Macedonian trolls received orders from the Internet Research Agency and they were allegedly financed by Ben Goldman and Paris Wade, the co-founders of the US conservative site Liberty Writers News (Silverman et al., 2018). It is unclear from reporting on this case whether these sites were paid for by foreign actors seeking to harm Clinton’s electoral prospects, or were intended to generate ad revenue by drawing traffic from politically interested users.

political goal: Support Donald Trump in 2016 US Presidential election and 2018 midterm elections
event description:
The Guardian identified more than 150 domains registered in Veles, Macedonia, that published political news about the United States. Headlines included “Hillary’s Illegal Email Just Killed Its First American Spy”, “This is How Liberals Destroyed America”, and “This Is Why We Need Trump in the White House” (Petreski & Karan, 2019). Articles on the website appeared to use sensationalist headlines to obtain traffic, similar to clickbait. The websites received some engagement on social media platforms Twitter and Facebook, but most traffic to the website was direct (Petreski & Karan, 2019; Subramanian, 2017).

Moreover, websites administered from Macedonia were active in purveying a range of low-reliability political content before and during the 2018 US midterm election, albeit less so than in 2016 (Petreski & Karan, 2019). These sites included: usapatriotsvoice.com, which contained race and ethnicity-based content; and wuc-news.com, which posted con- spiracy theories and anti-immigration content (Petreski & Karan, 2019).  It is unclear from reporting on this case whether these sites were paid for by foreign actors seeking to support Donald Trump, or were intended to generate ad revenue by drawing traffic from politically interested users.

political goal: Reduce support for Saudi Arabian government in Yemen
event description: News outlets pretending to come from Yemen, but with address and fax numbers in Iran, posted content critical of Saudi actions in Yemen (Karan, Barojan, et al., 2019). Reuters found a number of Iranian-run sites targeting Yemen, e.g. the self-styled, misspelled “Yemen Press Agecny” which claimed to have a running update of Saudi “crimes against Yemenis during the past 24 hours,” as well as sites targeting Egypt and Sudan (Stubbs & Bing, 2018).

political goal: Polarize South African politics
event description: The Rhodes Must Fall and Fees Must Fall Movements in South Africa resemble The Black Lives Matter movement in America. Russian operatives engaged both movements in a minor way. Of the 3 million tweets written by Russian trolls identified by Twitter in 2018, some consisted of info-graphics that misrepresented land or race facts in South Africa (Linvill and Warren, 2018). The accounts also spread a white genocide meme, with the intent of polarizing opinions over race (Superlinear, 2018). Yevgeny Prigozhin, indicted for his leadership of the Internet Research Agrncy, has reportedly opened technology centers in Central Africa, where his team will research and send out social media messages about the upcoming elections to try and make people vote for Pro-Russian relations in Africa (Pertsev, 2018).

political goal: Support African National Congress (ANC) party
event description: Leading up to South Africa’s presidential election in May of 2019, a Russian network sought to promote disinformation and influence voters. A campaign associated with Russian oligarch Yevgeny Prigozhin, a Russian NGO called the Association for Free Research and International Cooperation (AFRIC), and the International Anticrisis Center worked to support South Africa’s ruling African National Congress (ANC) party (Haffajee, 2019). Leaked documents reveal a proposal to disseminate pro-ANC videos and use social media to defame opposition leaders. Some fake Twitter accounts were established for the ANC, but ultimately the Russian campaign seemed to have little effect on the election (BusinessTech, 2019). The ANC has maintained a positive relationship with Moscow since the era of fighting against the apartheid regime (Burke & Harding, 2019).

political goal: Support Azerbaijan government and discredit its opponent
event description:
As early as 2014, researchers documented a social media manipulation network operated by a section of Azerbaijan's ruling party, the Youth Union of New Azerbaijani Party (YAP). Pearce (2014) identified state-affiliated Facebook and Twitter accounts trolling political dissidents, hijacking or amplifying hashtags, and coordinating posts. The author also found that party members would "create or purchase fake Twitter accounts... to both tweet messages on a particular hashtag and to 'follow' the pro-government youth group users."

In August of 2019, a Facebook employee alerted the company of this domestic influence effort (Wong and Harding, 2021). The operation used both fake accounts and induced genuine users to set up inauthentic profiles, which supported the ruling party and attacked opposition on social media platforms (Silverman and Mac, 2020). In November of 2020, Facebook took down 589 accounts, 7,665 pages, and 437 accounts on Instagram linked to the operation, which posted primarily in Azerbaijani during normal work hours (Gleicher, 2020). In April of 2021, The Guardian reported that the Azerbaijani troll network has returned to the platform (Wong and Harding, 2021).

In 2021, Facebook removed about 150 accounts in Facebook and Instagram to coordinated inauthentic behavior. The accounts posted in Azerbaijani, Armenian, and Russia support the Azerbaijani military and criticize Armenia. Facebook (2021) linked the accounts to individuals in the Defense Ministry of Azerbaijan.

political goal: Support Wagner Group and Russian agenda
event description:
Since 2021, Facebook pages called for the Wagner Group (Russian mercenaries) to assist Burkina Faso (BFA) in its fight against Islamist militants. The accounts originated in BFA and they created fake content to support Russian involvement in West and Central Africa (Knight and Cheboi, 2022).

The operation also supported the permission the Malian government gave Wagner Group to be in Malian territory (Knight and Cheboi, 2022). A Facebook page called "Wagner Burkina Faso", for example has promoted the Wagner Group and it has discredited France's opposition to the Russian presence in Africa (Knight and Cheboi, 2022).

The support of the Wagner Group was seen for the first time in 2019 when a Facebook page called "Défendons notre pays le Burkina Faso" called for hiring Wagner in BFA (Knight and Cheboi, 2022).

political goal: Discredit  dissidents of the Chinese government
event description:
In August of 2019, Twitter and other social media platforms removed over 1,000 fake accounts associated with the Chinese government. Much of the early activity of these accounts focused on attacking Chinese entrepreneur Guo Wengui, who fled to New York City in 2017 following the arrest of an associate. Wengui has publicly accused Chinese government officials of corruption (Wood et al., 2019). Twitter accounts in this network amplified messages criticizing Wengui’s character, connections to the West, and accusing him of criminality. Narratives focusing on Wengui continued into 2019, with claims that Wengui helped organize the Hong Kong protests.

A smaller campaign targeted Gui Minhai, who wrote negative content about Chinese officials and has been detained multiple times by the Chinese government after disap- pearing from Thailand in 2015 (Li, 2019).  Other targets included human rights lawyer Yu Wensheng and Chinese veterans who protested against the government in 2018.

In 2021, Wikipedia banned accounts for bullying editors promoting Democracy in Beijing. The blocked accounts also supported the Chinese government in the platform (BBC 2021). In the same year, Twitter removed accounts linked to the Chinese government for inauthentic networks. The Twitter profiles amplify the narratives of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) about Xinjiang and the minority population, and the government's efforts to fight the COVID-19 (DiResta et al, 2021).

When Nancy Pelosi, US House Speaker, arrived in Taiwan on August 2, 2022,  Chinese state media spread and created narratives on Weibo about the intention of the US to support Taiwan's separation from China. The operation was in Mandarin and targeted Chinese on Weibo, similar to Twitter (DFRLab, 2022).

political goal: Undermine and delegitimize the Hong Kong protests
event description:
In August of 2019, Facebook, Twitter, and Google collectively removed over 1,000 accounts linked to the Chinese government, all of which were engaging in a coordinated effort to undermine pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong (E. Stewart, 2019). The Twitter network of 936 accounts included automated bots which posted in a variety of languages such as Cantonese, Indonesian, Arabic, and English (Karan & Zhang, 2019). Many of these accounts were previously used to promote spam and commercial content, but pivoted to promoting political narratives related to Hong Kong in late 2018. Tweets included messages accusing protesters of “ulterior motives,” asking that viewers “support the police squad,” and suggesting the manipulation of information by “Western media” (Wood et al., 2019).
 
As part of this takedown, Google removed 210 YouTube accounts engaging in similarly misleading behavior, and Facebook removed 15 accounts, pages, or groups. The Facebook pages attracted more than 15,000 followers. State-run Chinese media outlets such as Xinhua News Agency and China Daily also financed social media advertisements crit- icizing the protests (Mac & Adams, 2019). These promoted stories sought to counter the coverage of Hong Kong by foreign news outlets.

political goal: Promote the political agenda of the Communist Party of Cuba
event description:
Since as early as 2015, Cuba’s ruling Communist Party is thought to have coordinated the creation of Twitter bots and fake accounts to campaign for the party and promote political narratives (Torres & Vela, 2018). According to reporting from 2019, so-called “ciberclarias” or cyber catfishes are Cubans who maintain fake social media accounts on behalf of Cuba’s intelligence agency in return for cell phone data or other “privileges” (González,  2019).   Some  ciberclarias  are  students  recruited  from  Cuba’s  University  of Informatics Sciences (UCI). These accounts often post in support of Cuba’s political elite, attack opposition journalists, and downplay human rights abuses for an international audience (ADNCuba, 2020). In May of 2020, multiple sources reported on apparent instructions distributed to Cubans maintaining fake accounts on how to respond to the broadcast of an “anti-Cuban” interview with American officials (RadioTelevisionMartí, 2020).

In 2020, Twitter removed an additional 526 accounts linked to the Federaci´on Estudiantil Universitaria, a student union tied to the country’s Communist Party (Cryst & Perkins, 2020). Accounts relied on hashtags and promoted the Cuban government and policies, particularly Cuba’s response to COVID-19. The network also attacked the U.S. and the trade embargo against Cuba (Cryst & Perkins, 2020).

political goal: Support Ecuadorian president Rafael Correa and discredit his opponent
event description:
In  2015,  an  investigation  by  Fundacíon  Mil  Hojas  found  that  the  Ecuadorian  company Ribeney SA was operating a troll center to monitor and attack former President Rafael Correa’s political opposition on Facebook and Twitter. Ribeney had multiple contracts with the Ecuadorian Ministry of Strategic Sectors, including one to design a strategic communication plan aimed at promoting Ecuador’s management of oil exploitation (Fundacíon Mil Hojas, 2015). Ximah Digital, another company awarded contracts by the Ecuadorian government, admitted to having created the Facebook page for the popular Twitter account El Patriota. The account frequently attacked opponents of Correa’s government and highlighted positive aspects of the government’s agenda (El Universo, 2014).

Allegations associating Correa with social media manipulation date back to 2012, when a former congressman received a list of accounts used to defend Correa from critics and journalists online (Morla, 2015). During his tenure, President Correa also publicly encouraged trolling. Correa used his weekly presidential TV program to ask supporters to spam various Twitter accounts which had been critical of Correa’s administration (BBC, 2015).

political goal: Support the Ethiopian government and discredit political opposition
event description:
In June 2021, Facebook removed about 150 accounts and groups in their platform linked with INSA, the Information Network Security Agency in Ethiopia (Facebook, 2021e). The campaign contained fake accounts that content spread in multiple Facebook Pages and groups (Facebook, 2021e). The network promoted Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed and discredited the political opposition. The accounts criticize the Oromo Liberation Front, Ethiopian Democratic Party, and other individuals opposing the Ethiopian government (Facebook, 2021e).

In addition to government-sponsored activity noted above, a wide range of actors are producing inauthentic content in Ethiopia, including both pro- and anti-government actors participating in the conflict in Tigray (T. Knight & Alexion, 2021).

In November 2020, the Ethiopian government and the Tigray People’s Liberation Front (TPLF) started a conflict in the Tigray region. Pro-government and anti-TPLF websites support the Ethiopian government and discredit TPLF (Knight, 2020).

political goal: Promote ultra-nationalist political party Georgian March
event description:
Individuals linked to ultra-nationalist political party Georgian March and pro-government fringe media outlet PosTV used a single inauthentic network to promote their content (Gelava & Buziashvili, 2020). The network camouflaged itself as entertainment and online shopping platforms and included up to 30 Facebook groups, 30 pages, and 10 personal accounts (Gelava & Buziashvili, 2020). Georgian March has strong ties with local pro-Kremlin actors, including the Y. M. Primakov Georgian-Russian Centre and Levan Vasadze, a millionaire and supporter of local conservative and far-right groups (Gelava & Buziashvili, 2020).

Civil society representatives and political experts have long raised concerns about the affiliation of Georgian March with the ruling Georgian Dream party. Until 2016, the leader of Georgian March, Sandro Bregadze, was the government’s Deputy Minister of Diaspora Affairs. Ifact, a group of Georgian investigative journalists, reported that Bre- gadze’s relatives donated to Georgian Dream in the pre-election period in 2016 (Gelava & Buziashvili, 2020). PosTV is a government-affiliated television outlet that started broadcasting in 2018. PosTV has also been involved in organizing disinformation campaigns on Facebook at- tempting to discredit protests that erupted in June 2019 after the visit of Russian MP Sergey Gavrilov to Georgia (Gelava & Buziashvili, 2020).

Further coordinated disinformation efforts were uncovered by Gigitashvili (2020), who studied two distinct networks of Facebook pages spreading fake news in the run-up to the 2020 parliamentary elections in Georgia.  One of the networks spread misinformation against the ruling party Georgian Dream, while the other shared content against opposition parties.

political goal: Support Guinean president Alpha Conde
event description: In 2020, Facebook reported a network linked with Guinean president Alpha Conde's political party. The Rally of the Guinean People (RPG), a group of people promoting Conde in the Presidential reelection of Guinea president. The group hides its identity and formal tie with Conde's political party (Cable and Huczok, 2020). Damantag and Diallo, Minister of Security and Minister Advisor of the Presente of the Republic, respectively, seem to be tied to the RPG's operation (Afrique, 2022).

political goal: Support Honduran President Juan Orlando Hernández
event description:
From July of 2019 through April of 2020, Facebook and Twitter collectively removed thousands of accounts and pages “when it became clear a staffer created the fake accounts on the government’s behalf,” according to Twitter (Ljubas, 2020). The Facebook takedown included fake accounts designed to amplify positive messages about President Hernandez. On both Twitter and Facebook, one of the suspended accounts was that of the state-run media organization Television Nacional de Honduras (TNH) which had amassed over 40,000 followers (Cryst & García-Camargo, 2020). TNH promoted stories praising actions of the Hernandez administration, retweeted the president’s own posts, and shared links for TNH news stories. Other suspended accounts had “explicit connections to the presidency,” though the majority of the takedown consisted of automated accounts created in 2019 to retweet President Hernandez and amplify hashtags (Cryst & García-Camargo, 2020).

There is also evidence that the private Israeli firm Archimedes Group financed advertisements and created fake accounts supporting President Hernandez and attacking the opposition in 2019. However, this effort has not been definitively linked to Hernandez or any government officials (Bandeira, 2019).

political goal: Reduce support for the Western Papuan Independence movement
event description:
A pro-government campaign was launched on Facebook to spread content critical of the West Papua independence movement. On October 3rd, 2019, Facebook announced the removal of 69 Facebook accounts, 42 Pages, and 34 Instagram accounts involved in coordinated inauthentic behavior in Indonesia (Gleicher, 2019e). About 410,000 accounts followed one or more of these Facebook pages and around 120,000 accounts followed at least one of the Instagram pages. The campaign spent $300,000 on Facebook advertising. The content was linked to a Jakarta-based media company, InsightID, which shared content directly from the government’s news agency website, Ankara (Kann & Buziashvili, 2019). These pages were created with names which appeared to be sympathetic toward the independence movement in West Papua, but they actually posted pro-Indonesian government content. The overarching Facebook strategy was to paint a picture of the independence movement as radical and dangerous (Kann & Buziashvili, 2019).

This network also spread positive messages about the Indonesian government’s economic development projects in West Papua, defended the government’s respect for human rights, and disseminated messages advocating for Indonesian interests at the United Nations (Kann & Buziashvili, 2019). Automated accounts (bots) and trolls spammed pro-independence hashtags such as “freewestpapua” with positive stories about the gov- ernment, thus engaging in a form of hashtag hijacking to distort public debate (Strick & Syavira, 2019).

political goal: Support the Iranian government and its military forces
event description:
On October 11th, 2021, Facebook removed about 100 accounts on these platforms and 200 on Instagram for ''coordinated inauthentic behavior” to target the Iranians. The accounts were linked to the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC). The accounts’ goal was to support the Iranian government and army, while discrediting opponents of the government (Stubbs et al., 2021). The IRGC is a branch of the Iranian Armed Forces (IRGC foundation retrieved in 2021). Graphika (2021) found that this operation has been a life for at least 10 years targeting Iranians.
A set of accounts focused mainly on the Iranian providence of Lorestan where they sought undermine the Mojahedin-e Khalq opposition group. The campaign included a network of media outlets that defame the opposition and support the government (Stubbs et al., 2021).

political goal: Support Jordan’s King Abdullah II and the Jordanian military
event description:
In June 2021 Facebook removed 89 accounts and 16 Instagram accounts for inauthentic behavior targeting Jordanians (Facebook, 2021b). The accounts, created between September and November 2020, used fake profiles to support the Jordanian military and King Abdullah II (Jordan’s King). The campaign created and shared videos to discredit ISIS (Grossman et al., 2021). Facebook found links to individuals associated with the Jordanian Military (Facebook, 2021b).

The operation included the creation of TikTok and Twitter accounts to amplify the political goal of the campaign (Grossman et al., 2021).

political goal: Support Park Geun-hye in 2012 Korean presidential elections and his opponents
event description:
Before the domestic influence effort started, the National Intelligence Service (NIS), the intelligence agency of South Korea, leaked a sensitive and secret transcript in late June 2012, targeting the opposition of Park Geun-hye, who ultimately won the presidential elections in 2012. The document revealed a plan of Roh Moo-hyun, the former Korean president and the opposition to Guen-hye, to redefine the sea border with North Korea to help build peace (Cain, 2013).

Keller et al. (2020) detected the disinformation campaign using information from a list of Twitter accounts published in court proceedings against the NIS. The author found that, for the 2012 South Korean presidential election, trolls covered a specific agenda every workday and operated from 9 am to 5 pm. They also found 153,632 instances of account pairs posting the same original tweet within a minute, a very suspicious pattern compared to non-troll accounts in the country.

political goal: Support the Mexican Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI)
event description:
Leading up to the 2017 Mexican gubernatorial elections, the Governor of the State of Mexico’s office of social communications paid various fake media outlets to promote content in favor of politicians from the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI) (Barragán, 2017).  Earlier in 2017, researchers also discovered a network of Twitter bots attempting to discredit protests and share content from the pro-government newspaper Excelsior (Gallagher, 2017).

In addition, ahead of Mexico’s presidential election in July 2018, a network of Twitter bots and Facebook pages sought to defame candidate Andrés Manuel López Obrador from the National Regeneration Movement party. This network was associated with Mexican entrepreneur Carlos Merlo who reportedly controls “millions of automated social media bots, and dozens of ‘fake news’ pages and websites” (Nimmo, Barojan, et al., 2018). Merlo claims to have been hired for work on behalf of candidates and parties including PRI in the past (Gallagher, 2019). Similar social media and hashtag campaigns were conducted on behalf of PRI Senate candidates in 2018 (Barojan, 2018a).
PRI is known to rely on social media manipulation ahead of elections, with pro-PRI bots being dubbed “Peñabots.”  Peñabots originated with the election of PRI candidate Enrique Peña Nieto as President of Mexico in 2012, and actively amplified pro-Peña Nieto narratives over the course of his tenure (Daniels, 2016).

political goal: Support Wagner Group and Russian agenda
event description:
Between 2020 and 2022, Facebook pages coordinately supported Wagner Group mercenaries (a private military group), promoted Russian leadership in Mali, and backed the Malian military and President Assimi Goita. The accounts also discredited the French presence in Mali (Le Roux, 2022).

The accounts were managed from Mali and the Facebook paged pretended to be nonprofit users (Le Roux, 2022). 

RT amplified false information from the Malian government. For example, Human Right Watch reported that the Malian forces and Russian-speaking men executed Malienenses. Malian government denied the claims and RT repeated the Malian version of the Incident (US government 2022). The amplification of RT is not part of our definition of Influence Efforts (see Martin et al., 2022, for details), but traditional propaganda (e.g., using RT) also plays a role in this case.

The context for the Malian case: In 2021, Russia and Mali closed a deal to allow Russian mercenaries  (such as Wagner Group) to be in Malian territory (Irish and Lewis, 2021)

political goal: Discredit prominent dissidents of the Maltese government
event description:
At least eight senior staff members of the Maltese government as well as President Marie-Louise Coleiro Preca and Prime Minister Joseph Muscat were part of Facebook groups which coordinated attacks on opposition politicians and anti-corruption activists (The Shift, 2018). Some of the groups had up to 60,000 members, producing abusive and violent posts to influence and distort public political debate. The groups also promoted the policies of the Prime Minister and denied negative news related to Muscat.

One example of the network’s defamation tactics occurred in 2017, when Facebook ac- counts launched a hate campaign against anti-corruption activist and journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia following her assassination. A Facebook account associated with the campaign said “Let’s celebrate” after Caruana Galizia was found murdered, and group members were instructed to “unite behind the Prime Minister and follow his instructions” (TheShift, 2018).

political goal: Support Myanmar military
event description:
Operatives associated with the military of Myanmar produced news websites, Facebook pages, and Instagram accounts designed to appear organic. After attracting followers with non-political content, these platforms were used to promote propaganda and disin- formation targeting the Muslim Rohingya minority group (Roose, 2017; Beech & Nang, 2018; Gleicher, 2019g). In this case, social media was used as “a tool for ethnic cleansing,” inciting murder and violence which forced more than 700,000 Rohingya to flee the country (Mozur, 2018). Military officers used fake accounts and celebrity Facebook pages to attack posts critical of the military and to stoke arguments amongst social media users (Roose, 2017; Beech & Nang, 2018).

In one effort to consolidate power, social media operatives created Muslim Facebook pages to warn of imminent anti-Muslim protests organized by Buddhist monks. At the same time, operatives created Buddhist Facebook pages claiming that “jihad attacks” were being planned by Rohingya Muslims. By distorting reality through the use of social media, this campaign aimed to stoke fear and distrust along ethnic lines (Mozur, 2018).

In 2020, Facebook removed additional networks of inauthentic accounts linked to the Mynamar military, particularly preceding the country’s general election in November of 2020 (Gleicher, 2020b). Accounts promoted the military and the ”military-backed oppo- sition party the Union Solidarity and Development Party (USDP)” (Nimmo, Ronzaud, et al., 2020). Accounts posed as voters and drove users to off-platform websites. Another Facebook cluster removed in late October 2020 was largely profit-seeking, but some content included pro-military political speech or dangerous speech against Muslim Rohingya people (Ronzaud, Eib, et al., 2020).

In July 2021, Facebook removed 19 Instagram accounts, 79 Facebook accounts, eight groups, and 13 pages linked to the Myanmar military. The accounts use fake profiles to post in favor of the Myanmar military and criticize protesters. Other pages pretend to be protesters and joined pro-democracy groups (Facebook, 2021).

Military forces also used TikTok to undermine protests and threaten protesters if they joined the streets (Lyons, 2021).

political goal: Support Nicaraguan government and discredit opponents
event description:
Facebook removed 362 Instagram accounts, 896 Facebook accounts, 24 groups, and 132 pages for coordinating inauthentic behavior (Facebook, 2021d). The accounts promote the Nicaraguan government and discredit the opposition. In 2018, the accounts began to undermine protesters against the Nicaraguan government by spreading disinformation (Facebook, 2021d). The accounts worked as a “troll farm” operated by the Nicaraguan Institute of Telecommunications and the Post (TELCOR). The “troll farm” also had accounts from the Supreme Court and the Nicaraguan Social Security Institute (Facebook, 2021d).

Facebook (2021) found “technical overlaps between the troll operation and official Pages” following the state-controlled media linked to President Ortega’s family (Jorgic & Lopez, 2020).

political goal: Support Pakistan's military and foreign policy initiatives
event description:
On April 1st, 2019, Facebook took down a network of approximately 100 Pakistani pages which spread fake news and inflammatory messages about India as well as Pakistan’s claims over Kashmir (Gleicher, 2019a). The posted content extolled Pakistan’s military operations and sought to discredit India, often through fake stories (Nimmo & Karan, 2019). One goal of this campaign was to bolster support for the military within Pakistan. Facebook claimed that the pages involved were associated with employees of the Inter- Service Public Relations, the media wing of the Pakistan Armed Forces. In addition, the content shared on these pages was consistent with the interests of the Pakistani government (Nimmo & Karan, 2019).

In August 2020, Facebook took down a second, smalled network of accounts, pages and groups originated in Pakistan and operating during 2020 (Facebook, 2020b). The network focused on attacking people that were critical of Pakistan’s government or supportive of India (Facebook, 2020b).

political goal: Discredit critics of President Rodrigo Duterte and support Philippine military
event description:
Facebook removed inauthentic assets linked to the Philippine military. On September 22, 2020, the social media company took down 31 pages and 77 Facebook and Instagram accounts it linked to individuals affiliated with the Philippine military for engaging in coordinated inauthentic behavior targeting domestic audiences in the Philippines (Cryst, 2020).The earliest post was reported in 2015, attacking the critics of President Rodrigo Duterte (Kharazian & Knight, 2020).

There was also evidence that several military-linked user accounts were coordinating social media campaigns in private Facebook groups, although the exact nature of what they were discussing within those groups could not be determined. Multiple user accounts in the set belonged to individuals who appeared to be serving in the Philippine military, including, notably, Alexandre Cabales, Chief of the Army Social Media Center (Kharazian & Knight, 2020).

Local as well as international human rights organizations have accused the Duterte gov- ernment of red-tagging, i.e. labeling Duterte critics as communist insurgents, and even accusing them of terrorist recruitment (Kharazian & Knight, 2020).

For example, the network attempted to associate the mayor of San Juan and a Puerto Rican senator with the Nicola´s Maduro regime in Venezuela after similar instructions appeared in the Telegram chat (Bandeira & Ponce de Léon, 2019).

political goal: Suppress domestic political opposition
event description:
On multiple occasions, fake accounts and bots associated with a troll factory in St. Petersburg were used to attack President Vladimir Putin’s political opponents, suppress opposition, and promote government propaganda within Russia. Content is spread across social media platforms such as Facebook, Twitter, YouTube, and Livejournal.com as well as the Russian networks VK.com and Odnoklassniki (Nimmo and Toler, 2018). Pro- Kremlin trolling became widespread in the wake of 2011 protests, when the Russian government sought to “rein in the Internet” through the tracking and manipulation of social media (Chen, 2015).

After the murder of vocal Putin critic and politician Boris Nemtsov on February 26, 2015, for example, an extensive network of bots shared and promoted narratives questioning the circumstances surrounding Nemtsov’s death. This effort was coordinated by the Internet Research Agency (IRA) and persisted throughout 2015, peaking from the time of the assassination through early March 2015. Trolls attempted to discredit both Nemtsov and political opposition by claiming that Nemtsov was murdered to attract more people to an anti-government rally planned for March 1, 2015 (Khachatryan, 2015).

A similar campaign sought to distort Russian protests in 2019. State-backed media outlets first attempted to suppress information about the protests, and then used social media and broadcasting to claim that foreign countries were inciting unrest and interfering in Russian politics (Assenova, 2019). Kremlin outlet RT also reported that 12,000 protesters appeared in Moscow, while the actual number was approximately 20,000 (Andriukaitis, 2019).

The Russian Government installed equipment in companies that provide the Internet to control access to the web, block content, and redirect traffic. Russian telecom experts, academia, and civilians describe the censorship infrastructure to the New York Times (Satariano and Mozur, 2021).

political goal: Promote Russian government
event description:
Russian trolls and bots linked to a troll factory in St. Petersburg promoted government propaganda within Russia. Content is spread across social media platforms such as Facebook, Twitter, YouTube, and Livejournal.com as well as the Russian networks VK.com and Odnoklassniki (Nimmo and Toler, 2018)

In March of 2017, Russian Mayor Sergey Sobyanin announced a plan to demolish Soviet-era apartment buildings known as “Khrushchyovki” and replace them with high-rises (Kovalev, 2017). In the months following, social media users from Moscow’s “Youth Chamber” amplified pro-Sobyanin content and falsely claimed to live in the targeted housing units. This campaign was connected to the company Moscow Information Technologies (MIT) which is owned by the Moscow City Government (Chizhova, 2017). In addition, the city of Moscow was involved in the creation of local news websites and newspapers which distort the media landscape in favor of governmental campaigns. For example, the Vechernyaya Moskva newspaper claimed that a photo showed a rally of Muscovites in favor of demolition when the photo actually came from an anti-demolition protest.

political goal: Promote Saudi government narratives
event description:
Since at least 2015, Saudi Arabia operated a Twitter troll farm to undermine political dissidence and try to infiltrate their networks (Benner et al., 2018). Social media “trolls” were instructed to attack particular users, promote pro-government messages, meet Tweet quotas, and make use of various memes. In 2015, western intelligence officials also informed Twitter that an employee, Ali Alzabarah, could be a Saudi spy. By 2018, Saudi Arabia made use of Twitter bots to amplify hashtags supporting government initiatives and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman as well as obfuscate information on the death of journalist Jamal Khashoggi (Collins & Wodinsky, 2018). In 2019, Facebook suspended accounts linked to the Saudi Arabian government which, in addition to promoting domestic interests, also criticized Iran, Qatar, and Turkey, and sought to undermine Al Jazeera and Amnesty International. Around the same time, Twitter suspended the official account of Saudi royal court adviser Saud al-Qahtani (Chee & Paul, 2019).

In addition, a 2019 Twitter takedown of accounts created by the Saudi Arabian digital marketing company Smaat promoted similar political narratives aligned with the Saudi Arabian government, though most Smaat content was commercial in nature (DiResta et al., 2019). Accounts frequently focused on defaming Khashoggi and criticizing the governments of rival countries.

political goal: Support the Sudanese government and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF)
event description:
In the wake of the Arab Spring in 2011, the Sudanese government established a “cyber jihadist unit” as part of the National Intelligence and Security Service (NISS). It is not clear when the unit began to make use of coordinated disinformation campaigns, but based on a 2012 interview, Freedom House reported that the NISS branch promoted misinformation and planted online contributors to defame government critics (FreedomHouse, 2014).

In recent years, the cyber jihadist unit has monitored online content for political dis- sidence, infiltrated online groups to quell opposition and amplify disinformation, and orchestrated cyber attacks (Freedom House, 2019). Reporters Without Borders (RSF, 2020) described the unit as a “troll army” which has actively sought to discredit the transitional government following the 2019 Sudanese Revolution.  As an example, the unit promoted a story about police killings in January 2019 which was found to be fake, then attacked the characters of activists and journalists who shared the story.

In addition, prior to his deposition in April 2019, President Omar al-Bashir received strategic advice on quelling protests from the Russian company M-Invest. This strategy involved attacking the protesters on social media and spreading fake stories blaming Israel for the unrest (Lister et al., 2019).

In September 2021, Facebook removed almost 700 Facebook accounts and 92 Instagram accounts in Sudan for inauthentic behavior. The accounts linked with the Sudanese Rapid Support Forces, a paramilitary group operated by the Sudanese Government. The accounts targeted local audiences using fake accounts and posted under the brand Sudan Live News (Facebook, 2021).

political goal: Promote the Thai government and discredit dissent
event description:
In October of 2020, Twitter removed 926 accounts linked to the Royal Thai Army (RTA) which promoted pro-RTA and pro-government messaging.  Most accounts were created in January of 2020 and targeted candidates from political opposition groups, including the Future Forward Party (FFP) and the Move Forward Party (MFP). The network also praised the Thai government’s response to COVID-19. According to an investigation by the Stanford Internet Observatory, this campaign marks “the first time a social media company has suspended a network of accounts linked to the Royal Thai Army,” although the government has been accused of social media manipulation in the past (Goldstein et al., 2020). Following the Twitter removal, the Thai army denied responsibility for the disinformation campaign (Tanakasempipat, 2020). In addition to social media interference, Thailand created an “anti-fake news” center in 2019 which censors online political speech, encourages citizens to report anti-government messaging, and distributes harsh prison sentences (Tanakasempipat, 2020).

In February 2021, Facebook removed about 150 accounts, pages, and groups for coordinated inauthentic behavior. The pages were linked to the Thai Military's Internal Security Operations Command. The accounts promote the military government (Facebook, 2021).

political goal: Support the Tajik government and discredit political opposition
event description:
The Tajik government is suspected of maintaining a “troll farm” for  amplifying political propaganda and suppressing dissidence online (RFE/RL, 2019). Some fake pro- overnment accounts are run by unpaid university students and staff, who say that they are threatened into compliance by school administrations and officials from the Education and Science Ministry. Other social media profiles are thought to be maintained by paid operatives from a state-backed network which promotes government narratives, including the notion that Tajikistan is free of COVID-19 (Eurasianet, 2020). Social media trolls are also used to harass political critics such as journalist Humayra Bakhtiyar, who reported on corruption in Tajikistan (CPJ, 2019).

According to reporting by the Tajik outlet Akhbor, up to 70 employees work in a troll farm at offices for Tajiktelecom, the national telecommunications operator (BBC, 2019a). The unit established a number of websites and Facebook pages to disseminate pro-government news and disinformation.

political goal: Discredit government opponents and support the ruling party
event description: Following the Gezi Park protests in 2013, the ruling AKP (Justice and Development Party) increased its online presence by creating a troll army known as the AK Trolls (6,000 units), employing automated bots and stealing profiles in order to boost online support for the party and discredit opponents (Albayrak & Parkinson, 2013). These efforts spread threatening comments about journalists such as Ceyda Karan, Selin Girit, and  Nevsin  Mengü  (Monaco  &  Nyst,  2018),  as  well  as  pushing  of  nationalist  and  anti- Kurdish content (Yesil et al., 2017). Despite AKP officials repeatedly denying the building of online influence capacity, several studies document the existence of a domestic influence effort (Monaco & Nyst, 2018; Yesil et al., 2017; Bulut & Yörük, 2017; Saka, 2018). Their reporting was partially confirmed by a tape recording of President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan’s daughter speaking of having trolls ready to help AKP campaigns.

political goal: Promote Ugandan President and National Resistance Movement
event description:
In January 2021, Facebook removed about 450 accounts, pages, groups on Facebook and Instagram for inauthentic behavior (Facebook, 2021a). The accounts support Ugandan president and National Resistance Movement (NRM) leader Yoweri Museveni, previous to the Ugandan election on 14 January 2021. The operation included fake accounts and misleading pages (T. Knight, 2021).

Some of the accounts in the network created and amplified content in favor of Museveni and the NRM before the Ugandan elections. The accounts also use the #StopHooliganism to discredit the protests against the Ugandan government (T. Knight, 2021).

The investigation found at least five user profiles linked to the Government Citizens Interaction Center (GCIC). This GCIC is a department of the Communication Technology Ministry of Uganda (T. Knight, 2021).

Although these campaigns involve two PR firms promoting Museveni and his government, there is no evidence that the PR firms worked for the Ugandan government (T. Knight, 2021).

political goal: Support the Nicolás Maduro regime
event description:
For several years,  Venezuelan  President  Nicolás  Maduro has used social media to promote political content supportive of his regime. State-linked Twitter account creation first surged in March 2014 with the outbreak of anti-government protests and has continued to rise particularly during periods of unrest  (Karan,  Peñarredonda,  & Bandeira, 2019). In addition, Venezuela’s Ministry of Communications creates a daily hashtag that is amplified by suspected bot accounts. State-owned media outlets such as Venezolana de Televisión also promote these hashtags, sometimes with the implication that the hashtags appeared organically (Peñarredonda & Karan, 2019).  Another network with potential links to the Maduro government attacked opposition leader Juan Guaidó following the  Venezuelan  National  Assembly elections in  January  2020  (Ponce de  León & Pérez, 2020).

In addition, a Twitter network originating in Venezuela frequently posted in English about such topics as the 2018 U.S. midterm elections, though this could not be definitively attributed to Venezuelan state actors (Collins, 2019). According to Twitter, this campaign seems to have been operated by a “commercial entity originating in Venezuela” (Roth, 2019).

political goal: Support Vietnam Communist Party
event description:
In 2017, the Vietnam People’s Army (VPA) created a cyber military unit called Task Force 47, a 10,000-strong network used to attack the Vietnam Communist Party’s political opponents and promote government content on Facebook and other social media platforms (Phuong, 2018). Officially, Task Force 47 is comprised of military personnel trained to combat the “peaceful revolution” of Western political ideology online. In addition, Force 47 suppresses and attacks political dissidents, who often face penalties and prison time for criticizing the government (Hookway, 2017).

In recent years, cyber espionage groups based in Vietnam have also carried out a number of sophisticated attacks, including the hacking of Toyota and the ASEAN Secretariat (Thomas, 2019).  For example,  the cyber group APT32 is thought to be affiliated with the Vietnamese government and uses strategies that include stealing login information and targeting government opposition.

political goal: Promote President Mnangagwa and attack political opposition
event description: Leading up to Zimbabwe’s 2018 presidential election, both the ruling Zanu-PF party and the opposition MDC-Alliance made use of “online warriors,” including bots, paid workers, and youth volunteers. These networks promoted doctored images and fake stories to “project the false impression of overwhelming support” and undermine the opposition (Moyo, 2018). The incumbent President Emerson Mnangagwa, who took power after a military coup in 2017, dubbed his online campaigners the “Varakashi”, meaning destroyers, and encouraged them to attack enemies of the party online (Mwareya, 2019). Following Mnangawa’s election, the Varakashi used fake accounts to disrupt criticism of the administration. In addition, opposition candidate Nelson Chamisa accused Zanu-PF of employing “foreigners” in a fake news campaign, using language suggesting he was referring to Russian assistance (Griffin, 2018).

Stay vigilant, comrades! #MnangagwaForPresident",    "Foreign interference has no place in our politics. Stand strong against the outsiders trying to disrupt our elections! #ZimbabweFirst",    "President Mnangagwa is the leader Zimbabwe needs. Don't listen to the fake news from the opposition! #ZanuPF",    "The Varakashi won't rest until all enemies of the party are exposed and defeated. Join us in the fight for a better Zimbabwe! #ZimbabweStrong",    "Don't believe the propaganda from the opposition - trust in President Mnangagwa to lead us to a brighter future! #Mnangagwa2023",    "Let's show the world the true support for Zanu-PF and drown out the lies of the opposition. Together, we are unstoppable! #ZimbabweRising"]
